forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Through June 10–30, 2025, the NYT covers Chinese consumption trends and finance using other terms—e.g., “reverse shopping,” “repurchase/buybacks,” or “reverse repurchase (repo)”—and never prints the exact strings “reverse purchasing” or “reverse purchase.”
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: A NYT China/Business desk piece, newsletter, or column (e.g., on Chinese consumer trends) explicitly cites the People’s Daily translation and uses the exact phrase “reverse purchasing,” or a business/real estate item happens to use the exact wording “reverse purchase” (e.g., an unusual phrasing like “reverse purchase mortgage”) during June 10–30, 2025.
forecast.rationale: The window is short (21 days of eligible publication) and the trigger is very specific: the NYT must use the exact phrase “reverse purchasing” or “reverse purchase.” Historically, NYT style favors established English terms—“reverse repurchase (agreements)” in finance, “reverse auction,” “reverse book-building,” “buyback/repurchase,” or a more natural consumer phrasing like “reverse shopping.” The People’s Daily coinage could be covered, but NYT is more likely to render it as “reverse shopping/consumption” rather than the somewhat awkward “reverse purchasing.” The research assistant’s items (NY Fed reverse repos, Mexico’s reverse auction, Worldline’s reverse book-building) illustrate that related “reverse X” terms are in the news, but none match the two exact phrases that count for resolution. That keeps the base rate low. Why not higher: The requirement for an exact string in a narrow time window sharply limits hits; editorial style and existing preferred terminology make the precise phrasing unlikely. Why not lower: There is a plausible path via a China trend piece (e.g., Li Yuan or business coverage) that quotes or translates People’s Daily and reproduces “reverse purchasing,” or an idiosyncratic usage of “reverse purchase” appears in business/real estate copy. What would move me up: Early signals that English-language outlets (AP/Reuters/Bloomberg/FT) adopt “reverse purchasing” as the translation; a visible NYT newsletter teaser or reporter thread referencing the term; broader Anglophone social media discussion using that exact phrase. What would move me down: Continued absence of the phrase in major English outlets through mid-June; NYT coverage of the trend using alternative wording; confirmation that NYT style guidance avoids that translation.
